questions.question_text_1: Latent demand in a demand-response curve is the area obtained when?
question_texts: Latent demand in a demand-response curve is the area obtained when?

options.option_text: Price is reduced below the identified optimal price
Price is increased beyond the identified optimal price
The optimal price is increased beyond the maximum available price
Quantity is reduced below the identified optimal quantity

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following distributions is/are Symmetric in nature (choose all that are applicable)?
question_texts: Which of the following distributions is/are Symmetric in nature (choose all that are applicable)?

questions.question_text_1:
(The following is a purely imaginary scenario)

An insurance company believes that people can be divided into two classes: “Class-1: Those who are accident prone” and “Class-2: Those who are not accident prone”. The company’s statistics show that an accident-prone person will have an accident at sometime within a fixed 1-year period with probability 0.4, whereas this probability decreases to 0.2 for a person who is not accident prone. It is assumed that 30 percent of the human population is accident prone. Given this information, answer the sub-questions.
question_texts:
(The following is a purely imaginary scenario)

An insurance company believes that people can be divided into two classes: “Class-1: Those who are accident prone” and “Class-2: Those who are not accident prone”. The company’s statistics show that an accident-prone person will have an accident at sometime within a fixed 1-year period with probability 0.4, whereas this probability decreases to 0.2 for a person who is not accident prone. It is assumed that 30 percent of the human population is accident prone. Given this information, answer the sub-questions.

questions.question_text_1: What is the probability that a new policyholder will have an accident within a year of purchasing a policy? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “1.235”, then enter it as “1.24”)
question_texts: What is the probability that a new policyholder will have an accident within a year of purchasing a policy? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “1.235”, then enter it as “1.24”)

questions.question_text_1: Suppose you learn that a new policyholder has an accident within a year of purchasing a policy. Then, what is the probability that the person is accident prone? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “1.235”, then enter it as “1.24”)
question_texts: Suppose you learn that a new policyholder has an accident within a year of purchasing a policy. Then, what is the probability that the person is accident prone? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “1.235”, then enter it as “1.24”)

(The following is a purely imaginary scenario)

An insurance company believes that people can be divided into two classes: “Class-1: Those who are accident prone” and “Class-2: Those who are not accident prone”. questions.question_text_1: The insurance company has to pay an insurance fee of Rs. 10 per accident if the accident happens in the first year. If the company has sold 1000 insurances in total, then how much money (in Rs.) will it expect to pay at the end of the first year for Class-2 people? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “Rs. 1.235”, then enter it as “1.24”)

(Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “Rs. 1.235”, then enter it as “1.24”)

questions.question_text_1: (The following is a partially imaginary scenario) The BA discourse is often cluttered with queries / requests related to solutions for Past Year Question Papers (PYQP). The course instructor, Dr. Milo, had been informing that students need to put in effort to find solutions by searching the discourse. However, the results seem to be disappointing. Therefore, Dr. Milo wanted to do a few basic analytics on discourse behaviour of students. Past student data was collected for the analysis. Past data was collected for the BA terms in Jan-2022, May-2022, Sep-2022, Jan-2023, May-2023 and Sep-2023. For each term, 150 randomly selected unique student IDs were sampled. Of the 150 student IDs, 75 were “Male” and the remaining were “Female”. The learners in the discourse have either “followed the instructions” or “not followed the instructions” or “have not accessed the discourse at all” (these three are referred to as access categories). Specifically, for the sample data in the different terms (in sequence of earliest term to later term i.e. Jan-2022 to Sep-2023) it was observed that 1. For the Male sample: 30, 20, 35, 35, 45 and 35 had not followed the instructions respectively in each term (i.e 30 male learners had not followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) 2. For the Male sample: 20, 10, 15, 15, 15 and 10 had not accessed discourse at all respectively in each term (i.e 20 male learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) 3. For the female sample: 15, 22, 33, 25, 20 and 20 had followed the instructions respectively in each term (i.e 15 female learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) 4. For the female sample: 30, 20, 25, 25, 25 and 10 had not accessed discourse at all respectively in each term (i.e 30 female learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) Moreover, Dr. Milo assumes that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Uniformly distributed between 4 and 75. A total of 6 bins of equal area are created for performing the appropriate statistical test. Each term is a sample point. Given this information, answer the sub questions.
question_texts: (The following is a partially imaginary scenario) The BA discourse is often cluttered with queries / requests related to solutions for Past Year Question Papers (PYQP). The course instructor, Dr. Milo, had been informing that students need to put in effort to find solutions by searching the discourse. However, the results seem to be disappointing. Therefore, Dr. Milo wanted to do a few basic analytics on discourse behaviour of students. Past student data was collected for the analysis. Past data was collected for the BA terms in Jan-2022, May-2022, Sep-2022, Jan-2023, May-2023 and Sep-2023. For each term, 150 randomly selected unique student IDs were sampled. Of the 150 student IDs, 75 were “Male” and the remaining were “Female”. The learners in the discourse have either “followed the instructions” or “not followed the instructions” or “have not accessed the discourse at all” (these three are referred to as access categories). Specifically, for the sample data in the different terms (in sequence of earliest term to later term i.e. Jan-2022 to Sep-2023) it was observed that 1. For the Male sample: 30, 20, 35, 35, 45 and 35 had not followed the instructions respectively in each term (i.e 30 male learners had not followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) 2. For the Male sample: 20, 10, 15, 15, 15 and 10 had not accessed discourse at all respectively in each term (i.e 20 male learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) 3. For the female sample: 15, 22, 33, 25, 20 and 20 had followed the instructions respectively in each term (i.e 15 female learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) 4. For the female sample: 30, 20, 25, 25, 25 and 10 had not accessed discourse at all respectively in each term (i.e 30 female learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) Moreover, Dr. Milo assumes that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Uniformly distributed between 4 and 75. A total of 6 bins of equal area are created for performing the appropriate statistical test. Each term is a sample point. Given this information, answer the sub questions.

questions.question_text_1: What is the probability that a specific term will fall in Bin-4 when performing the hypothesis test to check if Dr. Milo’s assumption that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Uniformly distributed? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “0.235”, then enter it as “0.24”)
question_texts: What is the probability that a specific term will fall in Bin-4 when performing the hypothesis test to check if Dr. Milo’s assumption that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Uniformly distributed? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “0.235”, then enter it as “0.24”)

questions.question_text_1: What will be the expected frequency in Bin-2 when performing the hypothesis test to check if Dr. Milo’s assumption that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Uniformly distributed? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “1.235”, then enter it as “1.24”)

question_texts: (The following is a partially imaginary scenario) The BA discourse is often cluttered with queries / requests related to solutions for Past Year Question Papers (PYQP). The course instructor, Dr. Milo, had been informing that students need to put in effort to find solutions by searching the discourse. However, the results seem to be disappointing. Therefore, Dr. Milo wanted to do a few basic analytics on discourse behaviour of students. Past student data was collected for the analysis. Past data was collected for the BA terms in Jan-2022, May-2022, Sep-2022, Jan-2023, May-2023 and Sep-2023. For each term, 150 randomly selected unique student IDs were sampled. Of the 150 student IDs, 75 were “Male” and the remaining were “Female”. The learners in the discourse have either “followed the instructions” or “not followed the instructions” or “have not accessed the discourse at all” (these three are referred to as access categories). Specifically, for the sample data in the different terms (in sequence of earliest term to later term i.e. Jan-2022 to Sep-2023) it was observed that 1. For the Male sample: 30, 20, 35, 35, 45 and 35 had not followed the instructions respectively in each term (i.e 30 male learners had not followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) 2. For the Male sample: 20, 10, 15, 15, 15 and 10 had not accessed discourse at all respectively in each term (i.e 20 male learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) 3. For the female sample: 15, 22, 33, 25, 20 and 20 had followed the instructions respectively in each term (i.e 15 female learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) 4. For the female sample: 30, 20, 25, 25, 25 and 10 had not accessed discourse at all respectively in each term (i.e 30 female learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) Moreover, Dr. Milo assumes that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Uniformly distributed between 4 and 75. A total of 6 bins of equal area are created for performing the appropriate statistical test. Each term is a sample point. Given this information, answer the sub questions.

questions.question_text_1: How many degrees of freedom is present for the hypothesis test used to check if Dr. Milo’s assumption that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Uniformly distributed?
question_texts: How many degrees of freedom is present for the hypothesis test used to check if Dr. Milo’s assumption that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Uniformly distributed?

questions.question_text_1:
(The following is a purely imaginary scenario)

A company sells two products (A and B) in four different marketplaces. In the first marketplace, the sales are made at the Forenoon (FN). In the second marketplace, sales are made during the Afternoon (AN). In the third marketplace, sales are made during the Evening (E). In the fourth marketplace, sales are made during the Night (N). Table-2 provides the data on the sales in the four marketplaces for the two products in the first 5 days on January 2023. Using this data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: The question of whether total sales in different marketplaces for product A and total sales in different marketplaces for product B are independent across the different days is being checked. Then what is the expected frequency for “Product-B” on “03-01-2025”? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “1.235”, then enter it as “1.24”)
